ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Metal enhanced fluorescence of Ag-nanoshell dimer

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The plasmon modes of Ag-nanoshell dimer on metal enhanced fluorescence (MEF) are studied theoretically. The amplified excitation rate of a dimer (two identical Ag nanoshells) illuminated by a plane wave for exciting a molecule located at the gap center is calculated. Subsequently, the apparent quantum yield of the emission of the excited molecule affected by the dimer is investigated. The multiple multipole method is used for the both simulations. Finally, the enhancement factor of the dimer on the overall photoluminescence of the molecule in terms of the two parameters is evaluated. Our results show that Ag-nanoshell dimer is a dual-band photoluminescence enhancer for MEF at the bonding dipole and quadrupole modes. The former is broadband, and the latter narrowband. Both bands depend on the gap size. Moreover, the average enhancement factor of Ag-nanoshell dimer for MEF with a Stokes shift is discussed.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Nanocomposites of nanoshell, a silica bead coated by a metal (Au or Ag) shell, have been developed in the last decade [1, 2]. In addition, the applications of metallic nanoparticles on the metal enhanced fluorescence (MEF) or so-called surface enhanced fluorescence have attracted a lot of attention [3–5]. According to Purcell’s finding, the molecular fluorescence will be affected by the environment [6]. Recently, some researches have proven that the fluorescence lifetime can be reduced dramatically by the surface plasmon resonances (SPR) of metal nanoparticles [2]. Moreover, the metal nanoparticle dimers have also been applied to the MEF recently due to the strong field enhancement within the gap region (a hotspot) for exciting a nearby molecule [7–12]. This is because that the strong plasmonic coupling between the separated but adjacent metal nanoparticles [13]. The plasmon mode of a dimer enhances the local electric field, particularly within the gap region [14, 15]. The gap mode of a dimer is not only useful to the MEF [16], but also to the surface enhanced Raman signal [17] and fluorescence resonance energy transfer [18]. More recently, the MEF of metal nanoshell has been studied to enhance emitter’s photoluminescence (PL), particularly for the fluorescence in the NIR regime [1]. The advantage of nanoshell is the plasmon band can be tunable by adjusting the thickness of metal shell and the size of silica-core [1]. Moreover, Au-nanoshell dimer possesses more advantages than a single nanoshell due to the gap mode [19–24]. According to the previous study, a single of the Ag nanoshell has dual-band MEF [25, 26]. In this paper, we are motivated to study the performance of Ag-nanoshell dimer on MEF theoretically. Since there is no analytical solution for this problem, the multiple multipole (MMP) method is adopted for the analysis [6, 8, 27].

Section1.Heading: Theory
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the configuration of Ag-nanoshell dimer (a pair of identical nanoshells) containing a molecule located at the gap center, where the radii of silica core and shell are denoted by a 2 and a 1, and the gap by d. Without loss of generality, the longitudinal axis of the dimer is assumed along the z-axis. The whole system is illuminated by a polarized plane wave with a wavenumber vector k, which lies on the y–z plane. The orientation angle of the molecular dipole moment is θ
d , and the incident angle of the plane wave is θ; both are with respect to the z-axis. We assume that the polarization (i.e. the incident field E
i ) of the plane wave is also on the y–z plane. This assumption is made, because this condition is the optimal one to induce the plasmonic coupling of the pair of nanoshells through the electrons’ collective motion. In general, the plasmonic coupling between the two nearby nanoshells is sensitive to the polarization of the incident plane wave. This is because that the plasmonic coupling of dimer can be induced only by the electric component of the long-axis polarization of the incident plane wave. If there is any x-directional component of E
i out of y–z plane, the plasmonic coupling is reduced, compared to the case without x-directional component.
Fig. 1
Configuration of Ag nanoshell dimer containing a molecule at the gap center illuminated by a plane wave. The radii of the outer shell and inner core are a 1 and a 2, and the gap is d. The orientation of molecular dipole moment is θ
d and the incident angle of plane wave is θ

A simple two-stage model for the molecular photoluminescence is used for analysis: the excitation stage of a molecule illuminated by a shining light, and the following emission stage for the excited molecule [4–6]. At the excitation stage, the electric field in the gap of the dimer is amplified as irradiated by an incident plane wave at a certain wavelength λ ex. For the model, the MMP method is used to calculate the total electric field E [27]. The excitation rate is defined as the normalized intensity at the molecular location, 1
$$ \varPsi (\theta,\theta_{d};\lambda_{\mathrm{ex}}) = \bigl \vert \mathbf{E} ( \theta;\lambda_{\mathrm{ex}} ) \cdot \mathbf{e}_{d} \bigr \vert ^{2} / \bigl \vert \mathbf{E}^{i} \bigr \vert ^{2}, $$ where e
d is the unit vector of the molecular dipole moment.

Once the molecule is excited, it behaves as an oscillating electric dipole and starts to emit its fluorescence at the next stage (emission stage). Since this emission is also affected by the nearby dimer, the radiative and non-radiative powers of the emitter at a specific wavelength λ em need to be studied. For this model, the MMP is also used to calculate the electric field (E
d , H
d ) induced by the dipole interacting with the dimer [6, 8, 27]. The radiative power P
r is the energy flow, which is allowed to emit to the far field, 2
$$ P_{r} = \frac{1}{2}\operatorname{Re} \biggl\{ \int _{S} \mathbf{E}^{d} \times \bar{ \mathbf{H}}^{d} \cdot d\mathbf{a} \biggr\}, $$ where S is any closed surface enclosing the electric dipole and the dimer, and Re denotes the real part [8]. The conjugate part of H
d is used for the Poynting vector,
$\mathbf{E}^{d} \times \bar{\mathbf{H}}^{d}$ . In addition, the non-radiative power P nr is expressed as 3
$$ P_{\mathrm{nr}} = \frac{ - 1}{2}\operatorname{Re} \biggl\{ \int _{S_{c}} \mathbf{E}^{d} \times \bar{ \mathbf{H}}^{d} \cdot d\mathbf{a} \biggr\}, $$ where S
c is the whole surface of the dimer, which is multiple-connected. The non-radiative power is the dissipating power inside the metal shells due to the Ohm loss of the metal. Subsequently, the apparent quantum yield is defined as the efficiency of this emission under the influence of dimer [13–15], 4
$$ \eta (\theta_{d};\lambda_{\mathrm{em}}) = P_{r}/(P_{r} + P_{\mathrm{nr}}). $$ Finally, the enhancement factor of the dimer on the overall photoluminescence of a singular molecule is defined as the product of the above two parameters [8], 5
$$ \alpha (\theta,\theta_{d};\lambda_{\mathrm{ex}},\lambda_{\mathrm{em}}) = \varPsi (\theta,\theta_{d};\lambda_{\mathrm{ex}})\eta ( \theta_{d};\lambda_{\mathrm{em}}). $$ The enhancement factor of MEF is a function of the excitation and emission wavelengths (λ ex, λ em), i.e., the enhancement factor depends on the Stokes shift of the fluorescence.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
In the following, the MEF of a typical Ag-nanoshell dimer of a 1=60 nm, a 2=40 nm is investigated, as shown in Fig. 1. Throughout this paper, the surrounding medium is water. The dielectric constants of the silica core and water are 2.1 and 1.77, respectively. The frequency-dependent Ag permittivity is referred to [28]. First, to identify the plasmon modes of Ag-nanoshell dimer, the extinction cross section (ECS) efficiency spectra of Ag-nanoshell dimer for different gap d (5, 10, 20 nm) are calculated, where θ=0∘. Here, ECS are the sum of the scattering and absorption cross sections, and ECS efficiency of a dimer is defined as the ratio of ECS to the cross-section area of a single nanoshell. In Fig. 2, the solid and dash lines represent the ECS efficiency spectra of Ag-nanoshell dimer and a single nanoshell, respectively. The peaks in these spectra indicate the plasmon modes. In addition, Fig. 2 elucidates that the smaller the gap the more the red shifts of these plasmon modes are [6, 19]. In the following, the case of d=20 nm will be studied systematically to demonstrate the role of Ag-nanoshell dimer playing on MEF. For example, the peaks of the bonding dipole, quadrupole and sextupole modes of a dimer of d=20 nm are at 705 nm, 440 nm, and 390 nm, respectively. These bonding modes are due to the electromagnetic coupling of the two adjacent nanoshells; these modes of a dimer are red-shifted from those of a single nanoshell. The dipole mode is broadband, while the higher order modes are narrowband. Moreover, the near-field electric fields and surface charge distributions at the dipole mode (λ ex=705 nm), quadrupole mode (λ ex=440 nm) and sextupole mode (λ ex=390 nm) are depicted in Fig. 3(a), (b), and (c), respectively, where θ=0∘. Obviously, the gap region of a dimer is a hotspot as illuminated by a light at the dipole and quadrupole modes. In contrast, the sextupole mode does not have this benefit of inducing hotspot in the gap region. In addition, the surface charge distributions of these modes show the coupling of the two nearby nanoshell. Furthermore, the amplified excitation rate of this dimer on a molecule located at the gap center is analyzed. The excitation rate spectra of Ag-nanoshell dimer on a molecule located at the gap center irradiated by a plane wave of θ=0∘ and θ=30∘ are plotted in Fig. 4(a) and (b), respectively. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), the results of θ
d =0∘ and 30∘ are shown for comparison. According to these spectra, we conclude that the optimal incident angle and orientation of molecular dipole moment are θ=0∘ and θ
d =0∘ to obtain the maximum excitation rates at the dipole and quadrupole modes. In particular, the excitation rate of the quadrupole mode is very sensitive to the incident angle, θ. In fact, we can raise the excitation rate by shortening the gap. However, the plasmon modes of the dimer are dependent on the gap size, also. Therefore, we should be careful to design the dimensions of the nanoshell dimer in order to obtain the optimal MEF.
Fig. 2
ECS efficiencies of Ag nanoshell dimer versus λ ex for different gap d (5, 10, 20 nm), where θ=0∘. Solid line: Ag nanoshell dimer. Dash line: single nanoshell
Fig. 3
Near-field electric fields and surface charge distributions at the (a) dipole mode (λ ex=705 nm), (b) quadrupole mode (λ ex=440 nm) and (c) sextupole mode (λ ex=390 nm), where θ=0∘
Fig. 4
Excitation rate spectra of Ag nanoshell dimer on a molecule located at the gap center with different orientation (θ
d =0∘, 30∘) irradiated by a plane wave of (a) θ=0∘ and (b) θ=30∘

Subsequently, we investigate the role of Ag-nanoshell dimer playing on the emission of an emitter (excited molecule). Figure 5(a), (b), and (c) show the spectra of the radiative power, non-radiative power, and apparent quantum yield of an emitter (θ
d =0∘) located at the gap center of dimer. The results of a single Ag nanoshell are also shown in Fig. 5 with a distance 10 nm between the electric dipole and nanoshell. Although the apparent quantum yield of a dimer is nearly the same with a single nanoshell, the radiative and non-radiative powers of the former are larger than those of the latter. This is to say that the Purcell factor of a dimer is stronger than that of a single nanoshell [6]. Therefore, the lifetime reduction of molecular fluorescence by a nanoshell dimer is dramatically serious, compared to a single nanoshell. From these spectra, the bonding dipole, quadrupole, and sextupole modes of dimer are observed again, which are red-shifted from those of a single nanoshell. The peaks are at 775 nm, 450 nm, and 395 nm, respectively; they are red-shifted from those of the extinction spectra (see Figs. 2 and 5). Although the difference of the dipole modes between the extinction spectrum and the radiation power spectrum are as large as 65 nm, their bandwidths are also large. For the other modes, the difference is small due to the narrowband. According to authors’ experience, these red shifts always exist due to that an electric dipole (a point source) can more easily separate these plasmon modes than a plane wave. In addition, the dipole mode makes the dimer a superior nanoantenna for an emitter’s emission due to the low non-radiative power, compared to the quadrupole mode. Figure 5(c) indicates that Ag-nanoshell dimer is a low-pass filter with a cutoff wavelength of 450 nm; the emitted photons with longer wavelengths are allowed to radiate to the far field, and the others are absorbed and dissipated by metal. Moreover, the 3D spherical plots and cross sections in the x–z plane of the far-field radiation patterns of an electric dipole with θ
d =0∘ at the gap center of dimer at the dipole mode (λ em=775 nm), quadrupole mode (λ em=450 nm) and sextupole mode (λ em=395 nm) are plotted in Fig. 6(a), (b), and (c), respectively. The pattern of Fig. 6(a) apparently exhibits the behavior of a dipole mode. In contrast, the patterns of Fig. 6(b) and (c) are not in accordance with the quadrupole and sextupole modes as we expect, which have four and six lobes. The discrepancy is attributed to that the coupling of the two adjacent nanoshells causes the degeneration of the radiation patterns in the far field. In fact, the near fields and surface charge distributions have confirmed these modes (see Fig. 3). Figure 6 demonstrates that Ag-nanoshell is an efficient nanoantenna for fluorescence emission. However, the far-field radiation pattern is manipulated by the dimer’s plasmon modes.
Fig. 5
Spectra of the (a) radiative power, (b) non-radiative power, and (c) apparent quantum yield of an emitter (θ
d =0∘) located at the gap center of dimer. Black: Ag nanoshell dimer. Red: single nanoshell
Fig. 6
3D spherical plots and cross sections in x–z plane of far-field radiation patterns of an electric dipole with θ
d =0∘ at the center of dimer at the (a) dipole mode (λ em=775 nm), (b) quadrupole mode (λ em=450 nm), and (c) sextupole mode (λ em=395 nm)

Finally, the enhancement factor of the dimer on the overall photoluminescence is obtained by combining the excitation rate and the apparent quantum yield. If the Stokes shift of molecular fluorescence is taken into account, the excitation wavelength λ ex and emission wavelength λ em are different. Here, we use the 3-stage model. The enhancement factors versus λ em for Ag nanoshell dimer on MEF for different λ ex are shown in Fig. 7, where θ=θ
d =0∘. These curves elucidate that Ag-nanoshell dimer is a dual-band PL enhancer for MEF at λ ex=770 nm and 450 nm. It seems that a Stokes shift can increase the enhancement factor, but not much at all.
Fig. 7
Enhancement factor versus λ em for Ag nanoshell dimer on MEF for different λ ex (450, 560, 630, 670, 770 nm), where θ=θ
d =0∘

We further consider the effect of the dipole’s orientation on MEF at the dipole and quadrupole modes. Figure 8(a), (b), and (c) show the excitation rate, apparent quantum yield, and enhancement factor versus the orientation (θ
d ) of the molecular dipole moment for Ag-nanoshell dimer on MEF with a Stokes shift. The solid and dash lines represent the results of λ ex=770 nm, λ em=810 nm, and λ ex=450 nm, λ em=500 nm, respectively. The former corresponds to the performance of the bonding dipole mode of the dimer, and the latter the bonding quadrupole mode. From Fig. 8(b), we can conclude that the apparent quantum yield is not sensitive to the dipole orientation, particularly at the dipole mode. In contrast, the enhancement factors at these two modes are very dependent on the molecular orientation, as shown in Fig. 8(c). The average enhancement factors for the two cases are 76.4 and 55.7, respectively. It again illustrates that the bonding dipole and quadrupole modes of Ag-nanoshell dimer can be used for MEF; if the excitation spectrum of the molecule overlaps one of the two plasmon bands, the MEF effect could be significant. In contrast, the third (sextupole) mode is useless for MEF, because of the low excitation rate and low apparent quantum yield. In summary, Ag-nanoshell dimer behaves as a nanolens to focus the incident plane wave into a hotspot, the gap region, at the plasmon modes. Moreover, it performs as an efficient antenna for the emission of a molecule with a preferred orientation (θ
d =0∘), along the longitudinal axis of the dimer, at the dipole and quadrupole modes. It is worth mentioning that Ag-nanoshell dimer can also be useful to enhance the photoluminescence of a quantum dot, which can be regarded an isotropic emitter without the preferred orientation. Our methodology can also be applicable to analyze the MEF of a dimer on a quantum dot.
Fig. 8
(a) Excitation rate, (b) apparent quantum yield, and (c) enhancement factor versus θ
d . Solid line: [λ ex,λ em]=[770,810] nm at the dipole mode. Dash line: [λ ex,λ em]=[450,500] nm at the quadrupole mode

Since the quadrupole mode of Au nanoshell in [6] is close to the absorption band (the interband transition, 525 nm), the absorption behavior is dominant over the scattering one. Therefore, the quadrupole and higher order modes of Au nanoshell dimer are suppressed. In contrast, the quadrupole mode of Ag nanoshell dimer is at 440 nm, far from the absorption band (330 nm). Therefore, the quadrupole mode of Ag nanoshell dimer is allowed to perform. However, the sextupole (third) mode of Ag nanoshell dimer is at 390 nm, close to the absorption band of Ag (330 nm), so the sextupole mode is not obvious in the scattering efficiency (plane-wave illumination) and radiative power (dipole excitation) spectra. Based on the above comparison, the Ag nanoshell dimer is a dual-band enhancer for MEF, while Au one is a single-band enhancer.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: The near-field and far-field behaviors of a molecule at the center of the gap of Ag-nanoshell dimer were analyzed during the whole process of photoluminescence. The enhancement factor of the dimer on molecular fluorescence was evaluated. Our results show that Ag-nanoshell dimer is a dual-band PL enhancer for MEF at the bonding dipole and quadrupole modes. The former is broadband, and the latter narrowband; the wavelength selectivity for MEF of the quadrupole mode is superior to the dipole mode. This is to say that if the excitation spectrum of the molecule overlaps one of the two plasmon bands, the MEF effect could be significantly strong. In contrast, the other higher order plasmon modes (e.g., sextupole mode) of Ag-nanoshell dimer are useless due to the low excitation rate and low apparent quantum yield. A smaller gap can provide a stronger excitation rate, but reduce the apparent quantum yield of emission. In addition, both plasmon bands depend on the gap size, also. Normally, the smaller the gap, the red-shifted these bands are. Moreover, these plasmon bands also depend on the thickness of metallic shell and size of the silica core. Of importance is that the excitation spectrum of a specific molecule should overlap with the plasmon modes (dipole and quadrupole modes) of the dimer for obtaining the maximum enhancement. The Stokes shift of fluorescence can slightly improve the MEF. Based on these features, we can design and tailor the properties of Ag-nanoshell dimer on demand for enhancing a specific molecular fluorescence. When the dimer gap becomes smaller than 2 nm, the tunnel effect between two metal nanoparticles could take place [29]. For the case with ultra-small gap, the nonlinear effect between the local excitation rate and the intensity of illuminating light should be taken into account.
